docs.lead_paragraph: The 98th Congress, which adjourned Friday, slowed the momentum of President Reagan's efforts to change the scope and direction of Government, restoring funds for health, education and welfare and reducing his military spending requests. It was a session rife with partisan warfare between Mr. Reagan and Congressional Democrats, who blamed each other for problems ranging from growing deficits to the bombings in Lebanon. As the Congress session drew to a close, the President and the Democratic lawmakers traded charges on who was responsible for closing down the Government for one autumn afternoon because of a delay in passing a spending bill. Mr. Reagan's political magic, which seems to be verified in public opinion polls, was scarcely evident on Capitol Hill. Unlike its predecessor, the 98th Congress repeatedly defied the President on economic and military issues but, like many another Congress in a Presidential election year, it was timid in tackling some tough issues.

headline.main: CONGRESS, IN ITS 98TH SESSION, SLOWED PRESIDENT'S PROGRAM

byline.original: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Alice Hall, desperate to lose weight, spent $52.95 on a bottle of pills that she saw advertised in a magazine. The advertisement showed a slender woman in a tent-size pair of pants that, according to the headline, no longer fit. By swallowing 10 capsules a day, the advertisement promised, Mrs. Hall too could lose 10 pounds in two weeks. She took the pills as instructed for more than a month but didn't lose a pound. ''I believed they were going to work,'' she said. ''I wanted to believe they were going to work. I'm not an idiot, but I guess I was gullible.'' And that is what worries the Food and Drug Administration.

headline.main: NEW EFFORTS TO INFORM PUBLIC ON HEALTH 'QUACKERY'

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans spent $355.4 billion for health care last year, representing 10.8 percent of the gross national product, a record, the Department of Health and Human Services reported today. Health spending from all sources, including governmental agencies and private insurance companies, averaged $1,459 a person, the department said in its annual report on health outlays. National health spending rose 10.3 percent last year, from $322.3 billion in 1982, the department said. The rate of increase was the smallest in a decade but was still above the rise of 7.7 percent in the gross national product, the overall output of goods and services in the economy, which stood at $3,305 billion by year's end.

docs.lead_paragraph: A record $100 million will be spent this year to provide food and shelter for the growing numbers of single homeless people in New York, but city officials say they still have no solution for those who live in the street and refuse assistance. These people, the hard-core homeless, have become one of the city's most visible social problems. Once mainly found sleeping in parks and in abandoned buildings, thousands of these destitute men and women now live in doorways or on sidewalks throughout the city, including such affluent areas as Madison Avenue and Park Avenue. Many Mentally Ill The street people, many of whom are chronically mentally ill, make up only a small percentage of the city's homeless population. But because they have become an inescapable presence in the lives of most New Yorkers, they are a major concern as city officials prepare to house and feed record numbers of homeless people this winter.

headline.main: THE CITY SEES NO SOLUTIONS FOR HOMELESS
